questions.prompt: Which complexity class contains all decision problems solvable by a deterministic algorithm in polynomial time?
options: P
NP
co-NP
PSPACE
questions.explanation: P is the class of decision problems solvable in polynomial time on a deterministic model. NP instead captures problems whose solutions can be verified in polynomial time.

questions.prompt: A problem is NP-complete if it is:
options: In NP and NP-hard under polynomial-time many-one reductions
NP-hard, regardless of whether it is in NP
In P and has a polynomial-time verifier
In NP and solvable in polynomial time
questions.explanation: NP-complete means both membership in NP (poly-time verification) and NP-hardness (every NP problem reduces to it). NP-hard alone does not imply membership in NP.

questions.prompt: Complete the statement: If $A \le_p B$, then a polynomial-time algorithm for _____ implies a polynomial-time algorithm for $A$.
questions.explanation: A reduction $A \le_p B$ transforms instances of A into instances of B in polynomial time. If you can solve B efficiently, you can solve A by reducing A to B and solving the transformed instance.

questions.prompt: If some NP-complete problem can be solved in polynomial time, then P = NP.
questions.explanation: If any NP-complete problem is in P, then every problem in NP reduces to it and is therefore also in P, implying P = NP.

questions.prompt: What is the output of the following TypeScript snippet?
questions.explanation: Literal 1 is false, literal -2 is false because x2=true so ¬x2 is false, and literal 3 is false. Since no literal satisfies the clause, `some(...)` returns false and that is printed.

questions.prompt: To show a new problem X is NP-hard, you should typically:
options: Reduce a known NP-hard/NP-complete problem to X
Reduce X to a known NP-complete problem
Show X has a polynomial-time verifier
Show X is not in NP
questions.explanation: To prove NP-hardness, you want to show X is at least as hard as a known hard problem A by giving a polynomial-time reduction A → X.

questions.prompt: Which statement correctly distinguishes NP-hard from NP-complete?
options: NP-complete problems are in NP; NP-hard problems may be outside NP
NP-hard problems are easier than NP-complete problems
NP-complete problems are in P; NP-hard problems are not
NP-hard means “not solvable by nondeterminism”
questions.explanation: NP-complete = NP-hard + in NP. NP-hard is a lower bound notion and can include optimization problems or even undecidable problems.

questions.prompt: Which is a valid polynomial-time verifier statement for a decision problem in NP?
options: Given an instance and a certificate, verify in polynomial time that the certificate proves a YES answer
Given an instance, find a certificate in polynomial time
Given a certificate, decide the problem without the instance
Given an instance, verify all possible certificates in polynomial time
questions.explanation: NP is defined by polynomial-time verification of a proposed certificate for YES instances. Finding certificates (search) is a different requirement.

questions.prompt: If A reduces to B in polynomial time and B is NP-hard, then A must be NP-hard.
questions.explanation: A ≤p B means A is no harder than B. If B is hard, A could still be easy (e.g., A could be in P) because hardness does not transfer “backwards” along reductions.

questions.prompt: Cook–Levin theorem shows that _____ is NP-complete.
questions.explanation: Cook–Levin establishes SAT as the first NP-complete problem by encoding polynomial-time nondeterministic computations as Boolean formulas.

questions.prompt: Which implication is known to be true?
options: P ⊆ NP
NP ⊆ P
P = NP
NP ∩ co-NP = ∅
questions.explanation: Any problem solvable in polynomial time can have its solution verified in polynomial time (using an empty or trivial certificate), so P is contained in NP.

questions.prompt: If a language L is NP-complete, then its complement is:
options: Not known to be NP-complete unless NP = co-NP
Always NP-complete
Always in P
Always outside NP
questions.explanation: Whether complements of NP-complete languages are NP-complete is tied to whether NP equals co-NP, which is unknown. (co-NP contains complements of NP languages.)

questions.prompt: If an optimization problem is NP-hard, its corresponding decision version is necessarily NP-hard.
questions.explanation: If you can solve the optimization version, you can answer the decision question by comparing the optimum to the threshold. This gives a polynomial-time reduction from decision to optimization.

questions.prompt: A polynomial-time Turing reduction (oracle reduction) is generally:
options: At least as powerful as a polynomial-time many-one reduction
Strictly weaker than a many-one reduction
Only defined for optimization problems
Equivalent to taking complements
questions.explanation: Many-one reductions make one call after transforming the instance; Turing reductions can make multiple adaptive oracle queries, making them at least as powerful.

questions.prompt: A problem is in NP if YES instances have certificates verifiable in _____ time.
questions.explanation: NP is defined by polynomial-time verification of certificates for YES instances.
